Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Do anemonefish exploit anemone sensory mechanisms to evade attack by their hosts?
Award.AbstractNarration: The relationship between anemonefish (clownfish) and sea anemones is one of the most widely recognized examples of symbiosis. A defining characteristic enabling this interaction is that the fish can swim unharmed among the stinging tentacles of the sea anemone. Despite over 50 years of research, the physiological adaptations enabling this interaction remain a mystery. What is known is that the protection involves the mucous coat of the fish and that sea anemones detect prey by sensing sugar chains that are attached to proteins through a process called glycosylation. The current study will investigate this question from two angles. First, to identify potential physiological mechanisms protecting the fish, mucous glycosylation patterns will be compared between non-symbiotic fish species and several species that have independently evolved interactions with sea anemones. The researchers will then test the effects of these glycosylation patterns on stinging responses of sea anemones. Second, the researchers will investigate the ability of anemonefish to gain protection from sea anemones that are initially hostile. High-throughput methods will compare naive and associating anemonefish to determine if they regulate gene expression, protein expression, or mucous glycosylation during acclimation to a sea anemone. This project also integrates the above research goals with education and outreach approaches tailored to UMass Dartmouth and the surrounding community. UMass Dartmouth is a predominantly undergraduate-serving institution, and over 50% of its undergraduates are first generation college students. An open-ended classroom research experience is being developed to reinforce genetics concepts taught in lecture through molecular laboratory investigations of genes related to the anemonefish-sea anemone symbiosis. In addition, three graduate students and ten undergraduate researchers will be trained on the project. Finally, the researchers are partnering with the New Bedford Ocean Explorium to develop education opportunities and teacher training workshops to enhance regional K-12 science education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The symbiosis between anemonefish and sea anemones is a complex adaptation involving various changes in physiology, body structure, and behavior. We focused on one aspect of this symbiosis: the anemonefish's ability to swim among the sea anemone's tentacles without triggering the stinging cells used to capture prey. 

Prior to our research, there were three main observations about this protection. First, the external mucus of the anemonefish protects it from attack by its host; if this mucus is removed, the fish is stung by the sea anemone. Second, naive anemonefish that have never before encountered sea anemones are usually protected from host sea anemones, indicating that the protection is innate to the anemonefish, not the host. Third, through acclimation behavior, anemonefish gradually increase physical contact with a potential host. 

Our first goal was a comparative analysis of multiple fish species that have independently evolved symbiotic interactions with sea anemones. One of our most exciting results was the detection of genes that may protect symbiotic fish from attack by their hosts. We used high throughput DNA sequencing technologies to sequence all of the RNA expressed in the skin of fish, including cells that secrete the external mucus. Eighteen genes were expressed differently between two anemonefish species and two closely related non-symbiotic species. These genes provide clues about the cellular and physiological processes that allow anemonefish-sea anemones partnerships. 

Our second goal was to test the hypothesis that anemonefish modify the protection mechanism to suit different host species. Host sea anemone species differ widely in venom toxicity and the adhesiveness of their stings.  The Clark's anemonefish (Amphiprion clarkii) interacts with 10 sea anemone species, each with different characteristics, and may alter their mucus to work best with a given host. In our experiment, individual Clark's anemonefish were kept under three conditions: (1) naive fish that had never encountered a sea anemone, (2) fish interacting with relatively benign bubbletip sea anemones (Entacmaea quadricolor), and (3) fish interacting with more venomous, highly adhesive Haddon's carpet sea anemones (Stichodactyla haddoni).  Using cutting edge protein analysis technologies, we found that anemonefish did not alter the abundance of proteins in their external mucus to suit different species of sea anemones. However, analysis of RNA produced in anemonefish skin told a more interesting story. Anemonefish interacting with bubbletip sea anemones expressed genes at similar levels to naive fish, suggesting that the fish do not need to change their protection to interact with this relatively benign host. However, anemonefish interacting with the more hostile Haddon's carpet sea anemones had very different patterns of RNA expression from both the naive fish and fish interacting with bubbetip sea anemones, differing at more than 600 genes. We concluded that, although Clark's anemonefish do not alter the protein content of their mucus, they regulate genes that may alter mucus in other ways in response to different sea anemone species.

Our findings have advanced understanding of this iconic symbiosis. We detected genes that potentially protect anemonefish from the host sea anemone and now know that anemonefish regulate genes in their skin to respond to different host species. Our ongoing research is investigating the specific roles of these genes in the anemonefish-sea anemone symbiosis, and how they affect the symbiosis at the levels of developmental biology, ecology, and evolution. How does expression of these genes change over an anemonefish's life? Do these genes explain why some anemonefish species specialize in one or a few sea anemone species, while others are generalists? What information do these genes provide about the evolutionary origins of the anemonefish-sea anemone symbiosis?

The third goal was to build upon the PI's background in mentoring research, integrating quality research and education, and developing additional opportunities for educational outreach in the community. First, with the support of this grant, the PI mentored and trained 4 graduate students, 20 undergraduate researchers, and 3 high school students in one-on-one research projects. 22 of these students were female and 8 were from underrepresented minorities. These students gained valuable skills in genetic analysis, data interpretation, and science communication. Most of these students continued on to graduate, medical, or veterinary schools, or started careers in the sciences. Second, the grant supported development of a new semester-long classroom research project that provided experience and training to 203 students, many of whom would be otherwise unable to work as a traditional undergraduate researcher. Finally, the "Scientist for a Day" event allowed undergraduate researchers to share their experiences and love of science with their families, and to expose younger siblings to science as a career path.  

Combined with the research, these activities advanced the PI's development as a teacher-scholar, developed human resources through mentoring and classroom research experiences, and advanced the research, education, and community outreach goals of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth.
